THIS REVIEW IS SPOILER FREE

I got this game when I was 9 years old. I'm 14 now, and replaying the story mode for the 7th time. This game quite literally improves on the first game in EVERY POSSIBLE WAY. The voice acting is incredible, the story as close to perfect as a video game can get (besides some small plot holes that are easy to look past), and the difficulty curve expertly crafted. Speaking of the difficulty curve, I had my friend over to show him my new computer, and he wanted to play Portal 2 (he had not played the first game either). He got about 1/3 way through the story mode, and though the tests took him some time to complete, by about 15 chambers in, he showed a solid grasp of the portal mechanics. The first Portal was hailed for its introduction to the player of the 2-portal mechanics and puzzles. Portal 2 copies over this system, adding some beautiful vegetation to the abandoned Portal 1 chambers to provide a nice call-back for returning players.

I'll touch shortly on the graphics of this game. Running on highest-performance settings, this game holds up surprisingly well. But part of me expected that, as Half Life 2 seems to still hold up (to a certain extent) as well. The environment (which I guess fits into graphics) cannot be hailed enough. I played Portal 2 before playing Portal 1, but I can't imagine the surprise of a returning player seeing how large the scale of Aperture Science is now. This game uses it's environment to instill the feelings of minuscule power and loneliness that every player felt in the original Portal, but I should say less so, as there is much more humor in Portal 2, which seems to keep your mind off deeper stuff like that. It is only after repeat playthroughs that you more closely analyze your empty surroundings, and feel said emotions.

Portal 1 was extremely innovative at it's release (from what I've heard... because I wasn't there). Portal 2 adds to the innovation with heaps of new mechanics and tests that build on concepts introduced in it's predecessor. The gels for example, add a layer of platforming challenge that forces the player to more closely look at their surroundings (light bridges and tractor beams could also fit into this). The lasers, and their respective cube, change up tests as well, by making you think about other uses for your cubes besides just button pressing.

While I want to keep this spoiler free, I think I should slightly touch on the story. The line delivery in Portal 2 is better than anything I have ever seen in video games, and maybe even in media in general. The passion of the actors flows through their performance, and there isn't a single line that pulled me out, or made me think "huh... that sounded weird." As well as great vocals, humor is one of the defining parts of Portal 2 for me. There were multiple times when my friend laughed out loud in reaction to jokes when he was playing. GLaDOS has an amazing passive-aggressive nature to all of her jokes, and Wheatly, well that is something that just has to be experienced.

Portal 2 is (and likely always will be) my favorite game of all time. I played Nier: Automata over the summer, and it genuinely made me question that statement, and while Nier: Automata arguably has a deeper story, fun but usually simple gameplay, and in my opinion almost as gripping characters, that game is ~20 hours long. Portal 2 is 3. The fact that Portal 2 uses 3 hours to create better characters than any 20, 30, 40 hour game I've played, is simply remarkable. These 3 hours are packed with more innovation, fun, intrigue, surprise, and character than most/all other pieces of media I've experienced.

I don't know how to end this review besides just saying that there's no game that has had more of an impact on me than this one. And no other game I would recommend more. If you've read all of this, thanks, and go play Portal 2.

Portal is one of my fav video games. I never got around to playing Portal 2, and almost 10 years after it's release, I've finally gotten around to. I'm really glad I did. It's a fantastic sequel, and one that holds up a decade after it came out. It was great to return to the world of Portal and Aperture Lab, and continue Chell's story. Although I unfortunately had been spoiled on most of the story over the last decade, it was still a satisfying plot to play through. I won't spoil the ending (even though this game is a decade old), but it was definitely a great one. It didn't wrap up everything, but it did conclude the character arches of Chell and GLaDOS in a way that was satisfying for both characters.

Gameplay wise, the game is as clever and ingenious as ever in it's puzzles. The use of portals combined with many other facets makes for a lot of mind-bending tests to overcome. Unlike the first Portal, which was focused on the player going through tests until the game throws them a curve ball, this game feels much more open from the start. It's definitely much more ambitious, and has a larger empathise on storytelling, and throwing the player from set piece to set piece. 

Although I definitely enjoyed this, on the other hand, I think that the more ambitious nature of Portal 2 makes the game feel a little cluttered. That said, I don't mind, because I think it works well for what Portal 2 is trying to be. Whereas in Portal you have no clue what's going on, here you understand what it is you're getting into. You know Aperture Labs is a hellish place, and you understand that GLaDOS is an insane homicidal A.I. Portal 2 does a great job at transferring that unique unsettling funny-but-also-terrifying feeling of Portal over; you feel a new sense of trepidation, one that derives from what you KNOW, rather than what you don't know. The game also does a good job of flipping that on it's head later in the game too, by again, putting you into new situations and new locations that provoke that strong sense of the unknown again.

The new character, Whealty, is an absolute blast. He's probably my favourite character. Granted there's not many prevalent ones to choose from, but Wheatly really is fantastic, and I fell in love with him immediately. He's the perfect comic relief side-kick for the mute Chell.
